title: Organonitrogen Chemicals from Oxygen-Containing Feedstock over Heterogeneous Catalysts

reactions.text: In industries, nitrogen is reduced by hydrogen via the Haber-Bosch process under high temperature and high pressure, producing ammonia at a scale of 140 million tonnes annually. Ammonia, therefore, is the most significant source to synthesize organonitrogen chemicals at present.

Aliphatic amines, for example, are produced from primary fatty acids and ammonia in multiple steps. In a first step, the fatty acids react with ammonia under high temperature to form fatty acid ammonium salts. Subsequently, the corresponding amides are produced after a dehydration step, followed by a second dehydration step to generate nitriles. Further reduction of nitriles under high pressure hydrogen afford primary fatty amines, mixed with secondary and tertiary amines as side products. The reaction pathway is also complex for aromatic amine synthesis. Ammonia is first oxidized to nitric acid, which further reacts with benzene to afford nitrobenzene, and finally reduced to aniline. Alternatively, benzene is transformed into halogenobenzene in the Friedel–Crafts halogenation using Lewis acids as catalysts. After that, transition-metal-catalyzed amination of aryl halides with ammonia affords aniline as the product.

In the conversion of glycolaldehyde to ethanolamine, Ru/ZrO2 reduced at 250 °C afforded the highest ethanolamine yield of 56% in the presence of 20 bar of H2 at 85 °C. Ru/Al2O3, Ru/SiO2, and Ru/HZSM-5 offered lower ethanolamine yields of around 23% to 27%, while Ru/Nb2O5 was totally inactive under the same condition. With further optimization, 93% yield was achieved with the Ru/ZrO2 catalyst. The partially reduced Ru/ZrO2 catalyst contained both Ru(0) and RuO2 species, where RuO2 was proposed as acid promoter for imine formation by activating the carbonyl group and metallic Ru-catalyzed hydrogenation of imine to amine. This catalyst was applied to convert 15 biomass-derived aldehydes and ketones with up to 99% yield and was used to produce 10% ethanolamine from cellulose in a two-step protocol via glycolaldehyde as the intermediate (Figure 5).

Interestingly, the authors observed a strong support-dependent activity: while Ni-TA@Al2O3 and Ni-TA@ZrO2 exhibited poor activity affording less than 20% yield in the reductive amination of 2-bromobenzaldehyde to 2-bromobenzylamine, TiO2-, ZSM-5-, and SiO2-supported Ni catalysts provided yields of 75%, 88%, and 96%, respectively, in the presence of 5–7 bar of NH3 and 20 bar of H2 at 120 °C. Importantly, tartaric acid reduced the NiO to metallic Ni during the pyrolysis step and made the Ni NPs in a spherical shape with smaller size (5–15 nm), in sharp contrast to the nanorod-like NiO (170–190 length and 15–20 nm thickness) formed on silica without tartaric acid.

As a result, the β-cyclodextrin-assisted Ni/Al2O3 catalyst could be used for at least two runs with only a slight decrease in conversion, while Ni/Al2O3 prepared without β-cyclodextrin deactivated after the first run as the conversion dropped from 57% to 5%. The β-cyclodextrin-assisted Ni/Al2O3 (2, 5 wt %) catalyst was further modified by adding a small portion of Pd (0.2, 0.5, 1.0 wt %). By preadsorption of β-cyclodextrin on Al2O3 before impregnating Ni and Pd precursors, the catalyst (5 wt %Ni-0.5 wt %Pd) achieved 90% conversion with 71% yield to 1-octylamine in the reaction between 1-octanol and ammonia at 160 °C after 4 h.

In Raney Ni-promoted amination of furfuryl alcohol, the selectivity to furfurylamine and tetrahydrofurfurylamine could be switched by changing H2 pressure. In the presence of 10 bar of H2, the major product tetrahydrofurfurylamine was produced in 94% yield at 180 °C. When H2 was not supplied, the reaction rate decreased significantly, and the major product became furfurylamine. The authors investigated the spent Raney Ni catalyst by X-ray diffraction and XPS and proposed that the catalyst deactivation in the absence of H2 was due to the formation of the Ni3N phase. In another report, Raney Ni was used to convert 2-amino-2-methyl-1-propanol and ammonia to 2-methyl-1,2-propanediamine. Even though the conversion was limited (46%), a high selectivity of 88% to 2-methyl-1,2-propanediamine was obtained at 185 °C after 7 h.

The produced hydroxyacetone was purified in 66% yield via fractional distillation with 90% purity. The second reductive amination step was catalyzed by a solid Ni catalyst in the presence of 76 bar of H2 in aqueous ammonia at 85 °C. 85% 2-amino-1-propanol was achieved, with propylene glycol as the major byproduct due to the high-pressure H2.

Ammoxidation of alcohol to nitrile generally follows an oxidation-imination-oxidation sequence, while the transformation of aldehyde to nitrile avoids the first oxidation step (Figure 16). Metal catalyzes the oxidation of alcohol to aldehyde, after which aldehyde readily reacts with ammonia to generate imine as the intermediate. Since imine is unstable, it quickly oxidizes to the final product nitrile. In principle, water is the only byproduct.

Ru(OH)x/Al2O3 was superior to all the ruthenium complexes examined and other heterogeneous Ru catalysts, such as Ru/C, Ru3+-exchanged hydroxyapatite and anhydrous RuO2, in converting 2-naphthalenemethanol to 2-naphthonitrile with 6 bar of air at 120 °C. Ru(OH)x/Al2O3 also efficiently catalyzed the conversion of various aromatic and heteroatom-containing alcohols to the corresponding nitriles with 65–96% yields, despite that a relatively long reaction time (up to 12 h) was required. Even longer reaction duration (16 h) was required for the conversion of aliphatic aldehydes.

Haruta and co-workers reported MnO2-, Co3O4-, and NiO-catalyzed ammoxidation of alcohols to nitriles with oxygen. MnO2 exhibited high activity, affording 100% yield of benzonitrile from benzyl alcohol in half an hour at 100 °C.

CoNi/γ-Al2O3 catalyst afforded an acetonitrile yield of around 82% from ethanol in ammonia gas flow at 380–420 °C. γ-Al2O3 supported ZnCr catalysts were applied to convert styrene oxide to phenylacetonitrile in 88% yield and to transform allyl alcohol to propionitrile with the highest yield of 66% at 420 °C.

In addition, a Cu/SiO2 catalyst was developed to convert benzyl alcohol into benzonitrile almost quantitatively at 340 °C. While these catalysts were active in transforming one specific substrate, their wide application in more substrates was not verified.

Mizuno’s group developed amide synthesis via nitrile hydration. They reported that the same catalyst for benzonitrile production from benzyl alcohol and ammonia (Ru(OH)x/Al2O3) could be used to produce benzamide with addition of water to promote the hydration of formed nitriles. It is a two-step reaction sequence, comprising a first-step benzonitrile synthesis using air and ammonia dissolved in tetrahydrofuran, followed by a second hydration step by adding water to the reactor.
With 10 mol % Ru(OH)x/Al2O3 catalysts, benzamide was achieved in 70% yield after 5 h at 120 °C for the first step and 24 h at 150 °C for the second step.

In practice, dehydration of hemiaminal is often a more preferred pathway with a lower energy barrier, providing imine as an intermediate. After dehydrogenation of imine to nitrile, amide is formed by one more hydration step.

In addition to γ-diketones, research efforts have been devoted to developing pyrrole synthesis from more diversified substrates. Recently, β-amino alcohols and secondary alcohols have been converted to pyrrole following a dehydrogenation-condensation sequence. Homogeneous catalysts based on Ru and Ir, and heterogeneous catalysts such as Ir@SiCN were responsible for dehydrogenation, while basic condition is required to facilitate the dehydration steps. Of note, by changing β-amino alcohols to γ-amino alcohols, the products from dehydrogenation-condensation reaction might become pyridines.

As mentioned in the introduction, pyrrole is commercially produced from furan and ammonia with zeolite catalyst at 320 °C. However, high reaction temperature and the requirement of a large excess of ammonia in the reaction are considerable limitations of the current process. Cao et al. reported a solid acid H form zeolite Y (H–Y) catalyst for the reaction of biomass-derived furans with ammonia and anilines at much lower temperatures between 150 and 180 °C.

The reaction between 2,5-dimethylfuran and m-methylaniline was selected as a model reaction. Since acid sites are required for the transformation, metal oxides bearing acid sites were tested, and SiO2–Al2O3 provided the highest 42% pyrrole yield. With this, a series of zeolite with varied Si/Al ratios have been further screened.

The H–Y zeolite with a Si/Al ratio of 2.6 was the optimum catalyst, affording 96% yield of target product. The authors claimed acid sites with moderate strengths were preferred for pyrrole synthesis, while strong acid sites would inhibit the condensation of organonitrogen intermediates. The H–Y zeolite achieved 62% yield of N-unsubstituted pyrrole from the condensation reaction between ammonia and 2,5-dimethylfuran in n-heptane at 150 °C after 3 h.

The transformation of oxygen-containing compounds and NH3 to organonitrogen chemicals is highly complex. It is not easy, if possible at all, to identify a simple descriptor and to establish a catalyst design strategy. Nevertheless, herein we make an attempt to understand the general activity of various metals in making amines, nitriles, and amides based on simplified DFT calculations. Considering C–H bond activation on the α-carbon of alcohol is regarded as the rate-determining step in most reactions mentioned in this Review, the activation energy of C–H bond cleavage under reaction relevant conditions may provide insights to understand the metal-dependent catalytic activity. We calculated the activation energy of C–H cleavage of a methoxyl group (CH3O) into a formaldehyde group (CH2O) + H with and without NH3 coordination over nine metals on selected facets as a model reaction (Figure 25 and Figure S1 and Table S1 in the Supporting Information).
